newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Cypriots protest against plans to scrap gay ban.
newsitem.headline: Cypriots protest against plans to scrap gay ban.

text.p: More than a hundred bearded monks, priests and their supporters protested outside Cyprus's parliament on Thursday against plans to scrap a century-old law banning homosexuality.

"Only an irresponsible or misinformed society would legalise an immoral act which affects the sanctity of marriage and family. It is a source of misery, guilt and infectuous diseases for those who indulge in it," said Savvas Michaelides, one of the priests who organised the protest.

Brandishing placards reading "No to sodomy" and "homosexuality = misery, guilt and AIDS" some 120 priests and members of the public blocked the parliament entrance in Nicosia for about an hour, vowing to return in larger numbers next week.

Cyprus has come under pressure from the Council of Europe to legalise homosexuality after the European Court of Justice in 1993 ruled in favour of a Cypriot campaigning to scrap the law, which dates from 1889.
Cypriot officials have publicly agreed with scrapping the controversial law, which criminalises homosexual activity and carries prison sentences between five and 14 years.
Moves to decriminalise homosexuality have been pending approval in parliament for the past two years, with all indications of a decision on it before the start of the summer recess in July.
But any move to change will come under strong opposition from the influential Greek Orthodox Cyprus Church. They say decriminalising homosexuality would violate traditional values.
Gay rights campaigners say opponents are misinformed.

"They think we are monsters from outer space," said Alecos Modinos, the architect who took Cyprus to the European court. "We are ordinary people who were not made homosexuals. We were born homosexuals."

The protesters remained unconvinced. "God is against it. He proved it when he destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah," said Evagoras Ermogenides, 39, referring to the biblical cities referred to in the Old Testament. "We must safeguard our morals."
